“Havoc” invokes plenty of chaotic disorder and grit in Gareth Evans's action-packed, ballistic style, though its narrative couldn’t escape the carnage unscathed. Undoubtedly, the film delivered exactly what the poster and marketing suggested: a consistently entertaining and ultra-violent ride through the gritty, corruption-filled city. However, it can also be a bit too chaotic for its own good when its story and characters are set aside amidst the disorder. Tom Hardy and the rest of the cast were suitable enough to carry the movie's average screenplay and restrained themes through its duration. As for Gareth Evans, he again showed off his action filmmaking bravura with the film’s delightfully violent and tension-filled sequences, despite the murky CGI spoiling the authenticity. It may not be a sensational comeback for Gareth Evans regarding the genre, but its chaotic nature had enough moments to satisfy most of the genre’s fans seeking undemanding entertainment on Netflix.

Tom Hardy ist als Hauptfigur genau der mies gelaunte Sack den man mag, schauspielerisch ok, inhaltlich eher flach. Havoc delivers an intense, fast-paced ride led by Tom Hardy, whose performance remains reliably strong. The storyline holds up well, offering enough intrigue to keep you engaged, and the acting across the board is solid. The action sequences, however, are a mixed bag. There’s a distinctive visual style in the driving and combat scenes—wobbly camera work and rapid cuts that feel almost like a video game cinematic. It’s unique, though it might not be to everyone’s taste. The gunfights lean heavily into spectacle, often crossing into unrealistic or even unintentionally humorous territory due to exaggerated gore and physics-defying shootouts. One recurring issue is the lack of realism in the weapon handling—especially the seemingly endless pistol magazines and minimal reloading. For viewers who appreciate detail in action choreography, this can be a distraction. Some fight scenes also come across as overly choreographed, pulling you out of the moment. That said, the film does pack a few surprises and moments of clever storytelling. The final act tries to ramp up tension, but it leans too far into over-the-top territory, which might undercut its emotional payoff. Still, the filmmakers clearly aimed for something bold, and there’s a lot of effort visible in both the visuals and production. Overall, Havoc is a decent watch if you’re in the mood for gritty action with a stylized edge. It doesn’t quite hit the highs of other genre standouts, but it’s not a waste of time either. A solid one-time viewing for action fans—just don’t go in expecting grounded realism

Havoc: A Cinematic Reflection on Karma's Wrath (Written through the eyes of a seer, not just a viewer.) Havoc, starring Tom Hardy, is not just a gritty action film about chaos and survival. Beneath the visceral violence and shadowy cityscapes lies a far deeper narrative, a story about karma, accountability, and the cost of choices. From the very first frame, the film mirrors the internal unraveling of its main character. The opening scenes aren’t merely setting up a plot, they’re setting up a confession, a slow, brutal reflection of one man’s sins catching up with him. By the end, when Tom Hardy's character accepts his fate, it isn’t resignation, it’s atonement. Few ever reach that moment of true acceptance in life, and Havoc captures it in its most raw, aching form. Throughout the story, we see that karma is not selective. The innocent, the guilty, the corrupt, and the desperate, all are swept into the same current of consequences. No one walks away untouched. The young couple, the boy and the girl thrust into the eye of the storm, play supporting roles that quietly become some of the most profound. In a world collapsing into itself, their survival feels almost mythic. Their encounter with the police officer, who chooses mercy over procedure, is a powerful psychological beat. In reality, such an action would never hold up in the lawful world. However, in the world of spirit and soul, where right and wrong are not always written in ink, mercy finds a place. She let them go not because she was weak, but because she recognized their humanity still flickering amidst the ruins. The film’s deeper moral hums like an undercurrent, right place, wrong time, or wrong place, wrong time, sometimes it doesn’t matter. Karma threads through everything, balancing the scales whether we are ready or not. It does not discriminate, it only fulfills. Technical brilliance One cannot overlook the masterful sound design. The use of dynamic compression and environmental layering created an immersive atmosphere that made every creaking door, every distant siren, every desperate breath feel like it was happening inches away. It wasn’t just a film you watched, it was a film you inhabited. The sonic texture pulled you under and held you there, refusing to let you stay a mere observer. Final thoughts Havoc isn’t just an action movie. It’s a karmic ballet danced in blood and consequences. It shows us that no matter how hard we run from ourselves, sooner or later, karma will knock, sin will speak, and fate will answer. And perhaps the greatest victory isn’t survival at all, it’s acceptance.

Released almost silently by Netflix, Havoc arrived in the catalog without the fanfare that usually accompanies the platform's big bets. There were no robust campaigns or big trailers promoting the film - only the magnetic presence of Tom Hardy in the lead role served as the big draw for viewers to press play. The rest of the cast, including the excellent Forest Whitaker, barely featured in the promotional materials, which shows where the production's focus is. Behind the scenes, there were no grandiose expectations either: the script and direction were handled by Gareth Evans, known for his work on the Operation Invasion franchise and the Gangs of London series, but still without a major consolidated hit on his CV. However, Havoc turns out to be a pleasant surprise for fans of the genre. There is no complex plot here, full of twists and turns or memorable performances worthy of awards. The movie doesn't pretend to be anything other than a brutal, direct and, at many times, extremely effective entertainment vehicle. Gareth Evans, in an interview, made it clear that his intention was to pay homage to the Hong Kong action films of the 1980s and 1990s, especially the classics of the subgenre known as “heroic bloodshed”. And even if the end result is not an impeccable homage, it is undeniable that the director delivers an intense, adrenaline-charged experience with action scenes that impress with their level of brutality and realism. The film exudes graphic violence with practical effects, precisely choreographed fights and camera direction that seeks to insert the viewer into the action. Blood gushes, bones crack and everything is handled with a rawness that borders on the visceral. It's no exaggeration to say that Havoc is one of the most violent and impactful films of recent times in this subgenre - and not in the gratuitous sense, but as a conscious stylization that harks back to the times when action didn't depend exclusively on CGI or frantic cuts. The combat sequences are brutal, dirty and believable, and two scenes in particular are the beating heart of the feature: long, well-directed and with a technical level worthy of applause. It's in these moments that the movie transforms itself, gaining life, rhythm and personality. However, outside of these sequences, the film stumbles. The narrative is shallow and uninteresting, with generic motivations and characters who develop little over time. The beginning is especially draggy and full of clichés, with Tom Hardy seeming to revisit mannerisms from his performance in Venom, delivering a performance that oscillates between tired and functional. The setting is generic and the construction of the universe limited. There are attempts to establish emotional relationships, especially between Hardy's character and secondary figures, but none of them are strong enough to generate real involvement with the audience. Even so, for those who watch an action movie expecting just that - action - Havoc fulfills its role with flying colors. It's not a complete work, far from it, but within the proposal to entertain with well-choreographed and visually striking combat scenes, it stands out. Brutality is the leitmotif of the experience, and Evans shows a special affection for these sequences, which have clearly been given more care than the rest of the script. The direction, although unbalanced, hits exactly where it should: in the physical battles, the weight of the impacts and the tension of the confrontations. In the end, it's clear that Havoc would be a completely forgettable movie if it weren't for these two key scenes that raise the bar for the production. They justify its existence and, in a way, redeem the lack of narrative depth and the poor development of the characters. If the viewer is able to let go of greater demands in relation to the script and immerse themselves in Gareth Evans' proposal - which is essentially to deliver stylized beatings and uninterrupted brutality - the film becomes a good choice for action fans who miss productions with physical weight and real impact.

This is very much a film of two parts. Part one is a deeply unconvincing police investigation/crime thriller, with unlikeable, two-dimensional characters and unexpectedly CGI cars that defy realistic physics. Part two is classic Gareth Evans action, and if you've seen The Raid: Redemption or the first season of Gangs Of London, you know this means crunchy fist fights, brutal injuries and incredible (if wildly OTT) gunplay. It opens with a truck being chased by a couple of police cars. Normally, I wouldn't mention this in a review, but it's noteworthy for being, as far as I could tell, entirely CGI, and not good CGI at that. The movement of the vehicles is just... off. There's simply no heft or weight to either the cars or the semi-trailer, and it's deeply off-putting. It's also worth mentioning because these weird CGI cars seem to be used every time there's a car driving faster than walking speed. Visually, Evans is going for a strange blend of pastel-bright colours and urban grime, to the point that I almost got a headache watching it. The story is patchy and difficult to swallow, and none of the characters are even slightly likeable or sympathetic, with the exception of Jessie Mei Li's rookie cop. But once the second half kicks in, all that goes to one side, because crunchy, meaty violence is what Gareth Evans does so, so well. When doing what he does best, Evans can tell a story with character arcs, empathy, and shifting allegiances even while character are hacking each other with meat cleavers and blasting one another to Swiss cheese with guns that can apparently shoot forever. It's a shame the first half is so bad. I'd like to see Evans team up with someone who can direct the quiet stuff and let Evans shine in the action, but in a project like this, written and directed by the same guy, we're going to see all the good and all the bad in equal measure.

Movie Review: Havoc One Star (and that’s generous) If Havoc set out to be the most aptly named film of the year, then congratulations—it’s a chaotic mess of cinematic misfires, stitched together with the subtlety of a car crash and the clarity of a blackout. Watching this film is like squinting into a malfunctioning flashlight while someone throws a bag of CGI debris in your face. The cinematography is so murky and underlit, you'd be forgiven for thinking your TV was broken. Action sequences, which should be the film’s bread and butter, are instead an incomprehensible blur of shaky cam and shadows. When you can actually make out what's happening—which is rare—it only gets worse. The CGI is so lazy and cartoonish it feels ripped from a mid-2000s video game cutscene, not a modern action thriller with a presumably decent budget. And don’t expect the story to save you. The plot stumbles from one contrived moment to another like a drunk on roller skates. Characters appear and disappear with no weight or logic, and any attempt at emotional resonance is drowned beneath the clatter of yet another brainless, derivative brawl. Havoc could have been gritty and gripping. Instead, it's just dim, disjointed, and dumb. If you're looking for a film that assaults your eyes, insults your intelligence, and wastes your time, Havoc delivers in spades.

Insane action fight choreography and hectic stunt chases for a gritty neo-noir. Welsh director Gareth Evans’ neo-noir action crime thriller Havoc (2025) on Netflix goes pretty hard. It’s not The Raid or The Raid 2, but I found Havoc solidly gritty and engaging. I wish the camerawork was less shaky as it can be seriously difficult to follow all the action. Evans’ direction features hardened criminals and desperate cops entering into brutal combat. Evans’ stylish direction is cool with wicked neon lights, heavy shadows, bloody violence, bleak worldview, and blunt honesty about the drug trade and homicide. Havoc opens on a chaotic car chase that looks super dangerous, the shootouts are very enthralling, and the fist fights are intricately crafted. The neon club fight in the center of the movie is awesome. It’s neat that Tom Hardy was also a producer on Havoc alongside Gareth Evans. Writer Gareth Evans crafts a dark story full of intriguing mystery, vicious killers, shady drug deals, deep corruption, and relentless violence. It’s neat seeing a conspiracy involving a disgruntled homicide detective have to rescue a corrupt politician’s son from the triad’s revenge. The drug deal gone wrong, shootout is crazy, then seeing the dark past of the cops was also interesting to me. I like how things escalate fast with surprising betrayals and shocking reveals. Casting director Kelly Valentine Hendry cast a lot of talented actors to portray these shadowy figures. Tom Hardy is totally gripping as the hardened homicide Detective Walker with shrewd tactics and brutal martial arts skills. Hardy is ready for the dark details and dramatic acting besides the intense combat. Hardy’s hard boiled performance grounds the drama and crime as Walker is willing to bend the rules to save himself. Michelle Waterson-Gomez’s assassin gets into a ferocious fist fight with Tom Hardy in the vicious finale. I adore the harpoon gun kill. Jessie Mei Li is excellent as the tough beat cop Ellie Cheung, who has joined homicide as the new girl. She’s as ruthless as the men here. Timothy Olyphant is also great as the stern officer Vincent. His intense crazy eyes and harsh words are as entertaining as his violent cop. Forest Whitaker is fun as the corrupt politician Lawrence. I love hanging onto every word of Whitaker’s. Justin Cornwell is surprising as the clever drug dealer Charlie, trying to move up in the underworld. Quelin Sepulveda is also engaging as the drug dealer Mia on the run and ready for a fight. Luis Guzmán is wonderful once again as Mia’s Uncle Raul. Sunny Pang is serious and compelling as the treacherous Ching. Yeo Yann Yann is fabulous as the Triad boss and Tsui’s vengeful mother. Serhat Metin gets immediately destroyed as Officer Cortez in the crazy car chase opener. Editors Sara Jones and Matt Platts-Mills’ chaotic fast cutting is both thrilling and hard to follow at times. Cinematographer Matt Flannery pulls off awesome shadows, visceral neon lighting, stunning close-up and medium shots, gritty wide shots, but gets too shaky during the action sequences. Production designer Tom Pearce’s gritty sets look cool like the neon futuristic look from art directors Faye Boustead and Sam Stokes. Set decorators Joelle Rumbelow provides all sorts of neat furnishings for the Triad clubs. Composer Tyler Bates’ hardcore film score is ominous. The hip hop soundtrack is really playful and exciting like the pulsing electronic songs. Gesaffelstein gets a real music showcase in the middle of Havoc. Sound designer Elis Howell Griffiths makes the assault rifle, pistol, and machine pistol gunshots sound heavy and massive. Costume designer Sian Jenkins’ all black outfits are fresh. Makeup artist Claire Pritchard does striking haircuts and bloody wounds. I did not care for the CGI blood, but the squibs look real. Overall, Havoc is fantastic fun for 105 minutes of violence and mystery.

The primary issue with Havoc lies in its appalling CGI and poorly executed visual effects. Filmed in England, United Kingdom, the film makes the questionable creative choice of attempting to pass off British locations as American cities. Rather than embracing its setting and adapting the story as a British narrative, the filmmakers opted for extensive computer-generated alterations to give the illusion of an American backdrop. This decision resulted in unconvincing visuals that resemble a distorted version of the United Kingdom, awkwardly dressed up to mimic the United States. The CGI is notably subpar, detracting significantly from the film’s authenticity. The artificial cityscapes and fabricated subway systems are not only poorly rendered but feel like a complete waste of effort and resources. The exaggerated camera shake further adds to the disjointed and chaotic viewing experience. Despite strong performances from Tom Hardy and several other talented actors, the film is ultimately weighed down by its technical flaws. The nearly two-year post-production process, largely due to the heavy CGI workload, appears to have done more harm than good. Had the filmmakers set the story in the United Kingdom, embracing the natural locations and cultural setting, Havoc might have delivered a far more grounded and visually coherent film. As it stands, the movie is an unfortunate example of style over substance, where misguided production choices overshadow the commendable acting talent involved.

Director Gareth Evans (The Raid) once again proves he’s a god-tier orchestrator of cinematic violence. The fight choreography is nothing short of savage poetry—elegant and brutal all at once. It’s not just action for action’s sake. Every sequence has weight, emotion, and purpose. It feels earned. This movie is raw. Relentless. Relentingly real. It’s a gut punch to the crime thriller genre. The cinematography is moody and immersive, the pacing breathless, and the tension so thick it practically drips off the screen. You don’t watch Havoc—you survive it.
